I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support and enhance road 
safety initiatives in the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) countries.1 It builds 
on the work of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) TA for Enhancing Road Safety for Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Member Countries.2 It will facilitate regional policy dialogue, 
knowledge sharing, and a coordinated approach to common road safety challenges. It will also 
explore opportunities for stand-alone road safety projects in CAREC member countries that 
address both infrastructure and other elements of the safe system approach at scale.3 
 
2.  The TA will equip CAREC member countries with the necessary skills and knowledge 
products to respond to road safety challenges and achieve their commitments under the United 
Nations Sustainable Development Goals.4 It is in line with ADB’s Strategy 2030, the CAREC 
Transport Strategy 2030, and ADB’s operational plan for regional cooperation and integration, 
2019–2024.5 It will also help implement ADB’s Safely Connected: A Regional Road Safety 
Strategy for CAREC Countries, 2017–2030.6  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Road crashes are a recognized problem in the CAREC region, where traffic fatality rates 
range from 8.7 to 18.1 per 100,000 people and the economic cost of road crashes ranges from 
1%–5% of gross domestic product.7 Road safety is an important pillar in CAREC 2030 to expand 
and improve trade and transport facilitation in the region.8 Several CAREC member countries 
have adopted national road safety strategies; however, they are generally under-resourced with 
no proper accountability.9 To achieve an adequate level of safety, CAREC countries need to 
coordinate road safety activities across the region. 
 
4.  Phase 1 of ADB’s TA for Enhancing Road Safety for CAREC Member Countries (footnote 
2), which was implemented from December 2014 to May 2019, focused on the safer roads of 
pillar 2 in the CAREC Road Safety Strategy.10 It built awareness of road safety engineering 
principles and developed the framework for regional cooperation in road safety. Phase 1 had 
three main outputs: (i) CAREC road safety strategy published (footnote 8); (ii) strengthened 
 
1 CAREC member countries include Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia,

2  ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for Enhancing Road Safety for Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
Member Countries. Manila (TA 8804-REG). 
3  Safe system approach involves reducing road crash deaths and injuries by adopting international good practice in 
road safety, and building on efforts for safer road infrastructure, safer vehicles, and safer road users. It seeks to 
maximize safety by improving road design and construction, ensuring that vehicles are safe, making sure that traffic 
laws are effective and well enforced, that road users understand how to use the road network safely, and that there 
are adequate emergency medical care facilities in the event of injury caused by a crash.

capacity of CAREC member countries to manage and coordinate road safety activities; and (iii) 
integration  of  road  safety  evaluation  tools  into  CAREC  road  projects.  Three  road  safety 
engineering manuals on road safety audit, safer road works, and roadside hazard management 
were published.11 
 
5.  The road safety strategy’s vision is to make CAREC international road corridors safe, 
efficient, and attractive for all road users. In implementing the strategy, ADB identified the 
following needs and gaps that the TA will address:  
(i)  Strengthen the governments’ capacity for road safety data collection and analysis 
using big data to guide road safety interventions. Poor road safety data generates 
limitations  in  every  aspect  of  road  safety  management  and  delivery,  including 
resource allocation, advocacy, intervention selection, and prioritization of resources.  
(ii)  Institutionalize the capacity enhancements on road safety engineering achieved in 
Phase 1. This includes initiating and developing a road safety engineering (RSE) 
unit within a national road authority, exploring the establishment of a national (or 
CAREC)  accreditation  system,  and  continuing  training  to  build  a  culture  of 
continuous  improvement  and  ensure  RSE  units  incorporate  international  best 
practices into the design, construction, and operation of their road networks.  
(iii)  Address specific actions identified in the strategy action plan, such as creating a 
CAREC road safety working group to share standards and regulations and review 
legislation and enforcement practices in the region.12 
(iv)  Develop  multidisciplinary,  cross-institutional,  and  regional  mechanisms  on  road 
safety, collaborate with South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) to 
share experience and knowledge on road safety, and embed the principles for road 
safety engineering developed in Phase 1 with other principles from the safe system 
to generate stand-alone road safety projects. 
 
6.  Road safety is a complex issue with multiple factors and interfaces, such as people, 
vehicle, roads, and institutions. It requires adopting systems which include both soft and hard 
interventions across multiple sectors and levels of government. Because many of the issues listed 
above are common to the CAREC region, the second phase of the regional TA approach will 
benefit all CAREC member countries, allowing efficiency gains from joint capacity building and 
knowledge sharing activities.  
 
7.  The TA will incorporate lessons and achievements from Phase 1 and other ongoing ADB 
TA including: (i) engaging more strongly at the national level; (ii) identifying opportunities to 
integrate  safety  features  into  road  projects;  (iii)  implementing  infrastructure  improvements 
simultaneously with soft interventions including enforcement, campaigns, and education; and (iv) 
achieving road safety with leadership, orchestrated action, and accountability. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: CAREC international road corridors made 
safe, efficient, and attractive for all road users (footnote 5). The TA will have the following outcome: 
 
11 ADB. 2018. CAREC Road Safety Engineering Manual 1: Road Safety Audit. Manila; ADB. 2018. CAREC Road Safety 
Engineering Manual 2: Safer Road Works. Manila; and ADB. 2018. CAREC Road Safety Engineering Manual 3: 
Roadside Hazard Management. Manila. 
12 This may include (i) standards for vehicle load limits, insurance requirements, and design standards; and (ii) 
legislation and enforcement practices, such as licensing requirements and practices, in the region.

3 
capacity of CAREC member countries to address key road safety issues in their respective 
countries strengthened.13  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Road safety engineering capacity in road agencies improved. The TA will 
initiate, develop, or expand RSE capabilities within a national road authority, or other appropriate 
body, by (i) developing an operational plan for an RSE unit to give it a clear statement of direction; 
(ii) conducting national, regional, and/or subregional workshops to provide specialist road safety 
audit and blackspot remediation training; (iii) accrediting attendees at audit workshops; (iv) 
reviewing  and  improving  engineering  design  standards  in  CAREC  countries;  (v)  exploring 
establishment of a national (or CAREC) accreditation system; (vi) exploring and developing road 
safety stand-alone projects; and (vii) cross-subregional knowledge sharing on RSE best practice 
with regional and subregional bodies, including SASEC. 
 
10.  Output 2: Cross-institutional road safety collaboration and data collection capacity 
improved. This will involve (i) partnering with the Asia-Pacific Road Safety Observatory to 
develop data standards for crash reporting, which may include a crash reporting form based on a 
minimum set of road safety indicators, a standard crash analysis procedure, and a centralized 
road crash database; (ii) sharing best practices and recommendations for cross-institutional 
collaboration for road safety; (iii) creating a CAREC road safety working group; (iv) making 
recommendations to improve policies and legislative frameworks across CAREC, such as vehicle 
safety standards, insurance requirements, regulations for used imports, access to crash data, 
vehicle loading and overloading policies, and licensing requirements and practices; and (v) a 
capacity development program, including (a) road crash data recording, reporting, and analysis, 
particularly fatal and serious injury crash data; (b) crash investigation and contributing factors 
analysis; (c) road user awareness; (d) enforcement based on general and specific deterrence 
principles;  and  (e)  cross-institutional  cooperation  for  improved  road  safety  policies  and 
management. The project team will encourage participatory approaches involving stakeholder 
groups,  including  youth,  transport  operators,  and  local  NGOs,  particularly  for  developing 
awareness and policy interventions. 
 
11.  Output 3: Intelligent road safety information systems developed and deployed. The 
TA  will  investigate  and  develop  selected  information  and  communication  technology-based 
solutions to improve road safety, which may include one or more real-time incident warning 
applications, intelligent speed signs, digital enforcement, mobile-based crash data collection and 
analysis software and tools, and other possible solutions which could be deployed to all the 
CAREC member countries. 
 
12.  Output 4: Knowledge products disseminated. Building on the RSE manuals developed 
under Phase 1, this TA will produce manuals and accompanying online videos on topics which 
may include (i) digital enforcement in CAREC member countries, (ii) traffic calming measures, (iii) 
crash investigations of hazardous locations, (iv) bicycle safety, (v) safety on mountainous roads, 
(vi) signs and line markings and delineations, and (vii) evidence of good and poor road safety 
practices (lessons learned in CAREC highway projects). ADB will select the final prioritized topics 
in consultation with the CAREC countries at the 2021 CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating 
Committee Meeting.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, of which (i) $300,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6) and (ii) $1,200,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.14 The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. A dedicated team from the Transport and Communications 
Division of the Central and West Asia Department and the East Asia Sustainable Infrastructure 
Division of the East Asia Department will implement the TA, including recruiting consultants, 
organizing  workshops  and  conferences,  and  monitoring  the  TA’s  progress.  The  team  will 
implement the TA in close coordination and consultations with ADB resident missions, East Asia 
Department, South Asia Department, and CAREC Transport Sector Coordinating Committee. TA 
project implementation will also follow the additional monitoring and reporting requirements 
specific to the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.15 
 
15.  TA implementation emphasizes coordination with World Bank and other development 
partners of CAREC program. ADB will implement the TA in partnership with other agencies to 
coordinate and enable sharing of expertise and/or experience.16 The project team will also 
collaborate  with  SASEC  and  implement  the  TA  alongside  the  Asia-Pacific  Road  Safety 
Observatory to ensure a holistic approach and no duplication of efforts in the region.17 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from December 2020 to December 2022. 
ADB will engage about 39 person-months of international and 43 person-months of national 
consulting services. ADB will recruit the international consultants either individually or engage a 
firm, which would be determined during implementation. Other activities to be financed by the TA 
may include study tours, seminars, and workshops.  
 
17.  Because the precise scope of the studies will be defined during implementation, ADB will 
maintain flexibility in engaging the specialists. Once the scope of the studies is defined and agreed 
upon with CAREC governments, the CAREC secretariat will prepare detailed terms of reference 
for the consultants. Where appropriate, ADB will consider lump-sum or output-based contracts 
for these services. Where the consulting terms of reference call for the services of a firm, ADB’s 
Procurement, Portfolio, and Financial Management Department may be consulted.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing Road Safety for Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Member Countries 
(Phase 2), and hereby reports this action to the Board.
